questions.text: A 38 year old farmer is brought to the emergency department by his wife with symptoms of sudden difficulty breathing, sweating and anxiety. On history taking he was spraying insecticide when this happened. The patient is emergently intubated and given atropine. Which of the following medications should be added along with atropine?
questions.solution:
ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING

Clinical features:

Treatment

  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison-fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastric lavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures-maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes-

(a) Atropine

It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.

It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action.

All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear

(b) Cholinesterase reactivators

Oximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.

Pralidoxime is ineffective as an antidote to carbamate anti-ChEs (physostigmine, neostigmine, carbaryl, propoxur)

Treatment should be started as early as possible (within a few hours), before the phosphorylated enzyme has undergone 'aging' and become resistant to hydrolysis.

Other oximes are

  1. Obidoxime -- > more potent than pralidoxime
  2. Diacetyl-monoxime (DAM) - lipophilic.

Option A : Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is occasionally used in atropine or scopolamine poisoning.

Option B : Propranolol is a beta-blocker used for hypertension as well as other indications.

Option D : Phenylephrine is an alpha-agonist used for hypotensive emergencies.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pralidoxime and diacetyl monoxime are cholinesterase regenerator compounds used for organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: A 78 year old man with Parkinson disease experiences worsening of his symptoms. He is already taking levodopa. Since the disease is characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons, leading to the lack of inhibition of cholinergic neurons characterised by cholinergic overactivity. The addition of which of the following medication is likely to help alleviate the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Antimuscarinic drugs currently used in the treatment of Parkinson disease includes

  • Trihexyphenidyl
  • Benztropine mesylate
  • They may act within the neostriatum through the receptors that normally mediate the response to intrinsic cholinergic innervation of this structure, which arises primarily from cholinergic striatal interneurons.
  • These drugs have relatively modest antiparkinsonian activity and are used only in the treatment of early Parkinson disease or as an adjunct to dopaminergic therapy.
  • Adverse effects result from their anticholinergic properties. Most troublesome are sedation and mental confusion. All anticholinergic drugs must be used with caution in patients with narrow-angle glaucoma

Option B : Reserpine is a norepinephrine uptake inhibitor occasionally used for the treatment of hypertension.

Option C : Doxazocin, an alpha-blocker, is used for benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D : Timolol is a beta-blocker used for glaucoma. Tubocurarine is a neuromuscular blocker used in anaesthesia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Central anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl (benzhexol), benztropine and biperiden are drugs of choice for the treatment and prevention of drug induced Parkinsonism

questions.text: A 56 year old man was receiving radiation therapy for throat cancer complaints of dry mouth after various cycles of radiation therapy. Later he was prescribed cevimeline for dry mouth by his oncologist. Which of the following mechanisms produces the therapeutic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist that has a long-lasting sialogogic action on lacrimal and salivary glands

In salivary glands, muscarinic M3 receptor activation leads to stimulation of phospholipase C and the formation of IP3 and diacylglycerol.

IP3 releases intracellular calcium, which increases secretion of saliva.

Option A : Sialogogenic action is due to M3 Receptors. ( Not M2)

Option C : M3 Receptors is Gq Subtype which acts via IP3 Pathway. ( Vs Gs - cAMP )

Option D : M3 Receptors is Gq Subtype which acts via IP3 Pathway.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pilocarpine and Cevimeline are used to treat dry mouth associated with Sjogren syndrome and that caused by radiation damage of salivary glands.

questions.text: An 75 year old agricultural worker is brought to the emergency department after an abrupt onset of bowel and bladder incontinence and muscle weakness. He is given oxygen and anti-dotal drug treatments. Which of the following drug mechanism would increase muscle strength in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has signs and symptoms of organophosphate toxicity that are caused by inhibition of cholinesterase and excessive stimulation of muscarinic and nicotinic receptors by acetylcholine.
  • The treatment of organophosphate intoxication includes administration of pralidoxime, which reactivates cholinesterase and leads to increased acetylcholine degradation.
  • The patient's muscle weakness is caused by prolonged depolarization of skeletal muscle.
  • Specific antidotes of Anti-ChE poisoning:

(a) Atropine

It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.

It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action.

All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear

(b) Cholinesterase reactivators

Oximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.

  • Pralidoxime is ineffective as an antidote to carbamate anti-ChEs (physostigmine, neostigmine, carbaryl, propoxur)
  • Treatment should be started as early as possible (within few hours), before the phosphorylated enzyme has undergone 'aging' and become resistant to hydrolysis.

Other oximes are

  1. Obidoxime -- > more potent than pralidoxime
  2. Diacetyl-monoxime (DAM) - lipophilic.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pralidoxime and diacetyl monoxime are cholinesterase regenerator compounds used for organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: A 20 year old boy was brought to emergency room after consuming some unknown substance. The patient was sweating profusely, saliva was drooling from mouth and tears were present. The boy had involuntary urination and diarrhea. On examination, the heart rate was 58 beats per minute and blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING

Clinical features:

Treatment

  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison-fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastric lavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures-maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes-

(a) Atropine

It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.

  • It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action.
  • All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear

Option B : N-acetylcysteine used for paracetamol poisoning

Option C : Naloxone is helpful in opioids poisoning

Option D : Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is occasionally used in atropine or scopolamine poisoning.

Key Takeaway:

  • Atropine: It is highly effective in counter-acting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.
  • All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly treated with atropine 2 mg IV repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear
  • Atropine is the drug of choice for early mushroom poisoning due to Inocybe species. (It is contra-indicated in poisoning due to Amanita muscaria).
  • It is used along with neostigmine (to decrease its muscarinic side effects) for the treatment of Myasthenia gravis and cobra bite.
  • It is also added to diphenoxylate (anti-motility drug) to reduce its addictive potential.

questions.text: An experiment on dog blood pressure was done by adding different drugs. The drugs added and the effects are as shown in the given figure. This experiment is done to demonstrate which of the following effects of Acetylcholine?
questions.solution:
Nicotinic actions of Ach

  • Both sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia are stimulated. This effect is manifested only at higher doses.
  • High dose of ACh given after atropine causes tachycardia and rise in BP due to stimulation of sympathetic ganglia and release of catecholamines.

Sequence of events in above mentioned graph

  1. Dog is given Acetylcholine (2 micro gram) causing fall in blood pressure
  2. Dog is given Atropine (2 mg ) → HR ↑
  3. And then dog again given Ach (50 micro gram) - No change in parameters
  4. After this, a high dose of ACh (5 mg ) given → BP & HR ↑ → Nicotinic action appear → Stimulate sympathetic ganglia

Key Takeaway:

  • Acetylcholine normally produces fall in BP due to its effect on muscarinic receptors to cause vasodilation.
  • However when given in very high doses, it can stimulate nicotinic receptors present on the ganglia that can result in increase in blood pressure.
  • However, to demonstrate this effect, muscarinic receptors should be blocked by giving high dose atropine.

questions.text: A 62 year old woman had no bowel movements 4 days after surgery to remove colon cancer. A diagnosis of paralytic ileus was made, and an intramuscular injection of neostigmine was given. The activation of which of the following pairs of receptors most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of the drug in the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
Uses of Neostigmine

  1. Myasthenia gravis
    • Neostigmine and its congeners are the first line drugs used to restore muscle strength.
    • They improve muscle contraction by allowing ACh released from prejunctional endings to accumulate and act on the receptors over a larger area, as well as by directly depolarizing the endplate.
  2. Postoperative paralytic ileus/urinary retention
    • The drug increases the availability of acetylcholine at cholinergic terminals, which in turn activates both the nicotinic neuronal receptors NN on parasympathetic ganglia and the muscarinic M3 receptors on smooth muscle.
  3. Postoperative decurarization
    • Neostigmine i.v., preceded by atropine or glycopyrrolate to block
    • Muscarinic effects, rapidly reverses muscle paralysis induced by competitive neuromuscular blockers.
  4. Cobra bite
    • Cobra venom has a curare like neurotoxin.
    • Though specific antivenom serum is the primary treatment, neostigmine + atropine prevent respiratory paralysis.

Summary of Neostigmine uses:

Key Takeaway:

  • Neostigmine is an inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase and thus acts like a cholinergic drug.It increases the availability of acetylcholine at cholinergic terminals, which in turn activates both the nicotinic neuronal receptors NN on parasympathetic ganglia and the muscarinic M3 receptors on smooth muscle

choices.text: Opening of K+ channels in sinoatrial node

questions.text: A 42-year old man was hospitalized with the diagnosis of myocardial infarction. Vital signs were blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 40 bpm, respirations 12/min. The bradycardia disappeared after an intramuscular injection of atropine. The increased heart rate was most likely due to counteraction by atropine of which of the following acetylcholine induced Actions?
questions.solution:
• By activating M2 receptors, acetylcholine opens K+ channels in the sinoatrial (SA) node.
  • This increases the outward K+ current, and the membrane becomes hyperpolarized. The result is a decrease in firing rate of the SA node.
  • By blocking M2 receptors, antimuscarinic drugs counteract the acetylcholine- induced opening of K+ channels in the SA node.

Option A : Acetylcholine-induced release of nitric oxide causes vasodilation, which could lead to reflex tachycardia. By counteracting this action, antimuscarinic drugs would decrease, not increase, the heart rate.

Option C : Antimuscarinic drugs can counteract acetylcholine induced decrease in cardiac contractility, but this has nothing to do with the increase in heart rate.

Option D : The blockade of presynaptic autoreceptors increases the release of acetylcholine from cholinergic terminals. This would decrease, not increase, the heart rate.

Key Takeaway:

  • Atropine works by blocking M2 receptors, counteracting the acetylcholine- induced opening of K+ channels in the SA node.

questions.text: A 23 year old young lady belonging to the film industry went to a dermatologist for cosmetic enhancement. Dermatologist gave her a series of subcutaneous injections by which her skin wrinkles are gone. Identify the following drug based on the mechanism of action provided in the given figure below?
questions.solution:
• Botulinum toxin acts by this mechanism.
  • As shown in the diagram, the drug is inhibiting the exocytosis of ACh.
  • Another features of botulinum toxin are:
    • Anticholinergic adverse effects (dry mouth, blurring of vision)
    • Use in wrinkles, spastic disorders, prophylaxis of migraine.
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Botulinum toxin A and B are highly potent exotoxins produced by Clostridium botulinum that are responsible for ‘botulism’ (a type of food poisoning).
  • These neurotoxic proteins cause long-lasting loss of cholinergic transmission by interacting with axonal proteins involved in exocytotic release of ACh.
  • Localized injection of minute quantity of botulinum toxin A (BOTOX) can be used in the treatment of a number of spastic and other neurological conditions like
    • Blepharospasm
    • Spastic cerebral palsy
    • Strabismus
    • Spasmodic torticollis
    • Nystagmus
    • Hemifacial spasm
    • Post stroke spasticity
    • Spasmodic dysphonia
    • Axillary hyperhidrosis
  • All of which are due to overactivity of cholinergic nerves.
  • It is being employed popularly as beauty treatment for removal of age-related facial wrinkles.
  • However, incorrect injection or overdose can be dangerous; ptosis, diplopia, facial swelling, dry mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, muscular weakness and even respiratory paralysis has occurred.

Option A: Hemicholinium blocks choline uptake (the rate limiting step in Ach synthesis).

Option B: Vesamicol blocks the transport of ACh into the synaptic vesicles.

Option D: Physostigmine is a lipid soluble reversible anticholinesterase. It can cross blood brain barrier and result in central adverse effects

Key Takeaway:

  • Botulinum toxin type A has been approved for treatment of strabismus, blepharospasm, cervical dystonia and glabellar lines acting via inhibiting the exocytosis of ACh

choices.text: Increased tone of the bladder trigone

questions.text: A 79-year-old female resident of a nursing home was recently diagnosed with urinary overflow incontinence due to an atonic bladder, and a treatment with Bethanechol was prescribed. Which of the following actions most likely mediated the therapeutic effectiveness of the drug in the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
• Overflow incontinence occurs when the weight of urine in a distended bladder overcomes outlet resistance.
  • It results from an anatomical outlet obstruction or an atonic bladder, as in this case.
  • Bethanechol is a cholinergic agonist that primarily activates muscarinic M3
  • This activation causes a contraction of the detrusor muscle of the bladder; therefore, the amount of bladder space that can be filled (i.e., the distensibility of the bladder, or it's compliance) is decreased
  • It also has been used in postoperative/postpartum non-obstructive urinary retention, neurogenic bladder to promote urination.
  • It can afford symptomatic relief in congenital megacolon.
  • Side effects are prominent:
    • Belching
    • Colic
    • Involuntary urination
    • Defecation
    • Flushing
    • Sweating
    • Fall in BP
    • Bronchospasm

Option A, B, D : Activation of M3 receptors causes effects opposite to those described

Key Takeaway:

  • Bethanechol is mainly used for its action on the urinary bladder and has no nicotinic activity. Therefore used in postoperative urinary retention.

questions.text: The cardiovascular effects of a new autonomic drug that does not cross the blood-brain barrier were evaluated in a healthy volunteer. The drug was administered intravenously, and the results are presented below in a table. Which of the following receptors did the drug most likely activate?
questions.solution:
• Activation of α1 receptors contracts vascular smooth muscle.
  • This will increase the systolic blood pressure (which is dependent on both cardiac output and total peripheral resistance [TPR]), as well as diastolic blood pressure (which is dependent mainly on TPR).
  • The increase in mean blood pressure causes an activation of the baroreceptor reflex, which in turn will decrease the heart rate.

Adrenergic Receptors

Option B : Activation of β2receptors would cause a decrease, not an increase of TPR, because β2 receptors are abundant in skeletal muscle vessels.

Option C : Activation of D1 receptors would cause a dilation of splanchnic and renal vessels; therefore, the diastolic blood pressure would decrease, not increase.

Option D : Activation of M2 receptors would decrease the heart contractility and rate, which in turn would decrease cardiac output. Therefore, the systolic blood pressure would decrease, not increase.

Key Takeaway:

  • Noradrenaline causes rise in systolic, diastolic and mean BP; it does not cause vasodilatation (no β2 action), peripheral resistance increases consistently due to α action.

questions.text: An intravenous injection of drug X was given to a laboratory animal before and after the administration of atropine, and the heart rate was recorded. The results are depicted below in a graph. Which of the following drugs was most likely drug X?
questions.solution:
• The drug causes a decrease in heart rate that is reversed by a pretreatment with atropine.
  • This suggests that the bradycardia is caused by a reflex vagal discharge.
  • Norepinephrine is the only listed drug that causes a vagal reflex bradycardia strong enough to overcome its own direct tachycardic effect.
  • When the reflex vagal discharge is blocked by atropine, the direct tachycardic effect of norepinephrine becomes evident.

Option A : Adrenaline given by slow i.v. infusion or s.c. injection causes rise in systolic but fall in diastolic BP; peripheral resistance decreases because vascular β2 receptors are more sensitive than α receptors.

Option C: Isoprenaline causes rise in systolic but marked fall in diastolic BP (β1-cardiac stimulation, β2- vasodilatation). The mean BP generally falls.

Option D: Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist. The only prominent action of clinically employed doses (2-8 μg/kg/min i.v. infusion) is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.

Comparative effects of iv infusion of following agents:

Key Takeaway:

  • Noradrenaline causes rise in systolic, diastolic and mean BP; it does not cause vasodilatation (no β2 action), peripheral resistance increases consistently due to α action.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought in by his parents to the paediatric department for complaints of hyperactivity at school. He is also inattentive and impulsive at home. After a detailed interview, the physician decides to give the boy amphetamine containing medication for presumed attention hyperactivity disorder. By which of the following mechanisms Amphetamine relieves symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)?
questions.solution:
Amphetamine and similar compounds are stimulants used for treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in which they are thought to act centrally to increase attention span.

  • Attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder (ADHD):
    • It is also called minimal brain dysfunction, and is usually detected in childhood.
    • The sufferer is considered a 'hyperkinetic child'. Amphetamines have an apparently paradoxical effect to calm down hyperkinetic children.
    • This disorder is recognized as a mild grade of mental retardation or a reduction in the ability to concentrate, i.e. the span of time for which attention can be focused on a subject is abbreviated.
    • Amphetamines by increasing attention span improve behaviour and performance in studies.
  • Amphetamines
    • These are synthetic compounds, orally active with relatively long duration (4-6 hours).
    • Maximal selectivity is exhibited by dextroamphetamine and methamphetamine, which in the usual doses produce few peripheral effects.
    • The central actions of amphetamines are largely mediated by release of NA from adrenergic neurons in the brain.
    • The central effects include
    • Alertness
    • Increased
    • Concentration and attention span
    • Postponement Of sleep
    • Euphoria
    • Talkativeness
    • Increased work capacity
    • Fatigue is allayed
    • Athletic performance is improved temporarily followed by deterioration.

Option A : Currently, there is no medication on the market that inhibits reuptake of epinephrine.

Option C : Blocking of the effects of norepinephrine will not alleviate symptoms of ADHD.

Option D : Serotonin reuptake inhibitors are used for depression and some other conditions.

Key Takeaway:

Methylphenidate is the preferred drug for the treatment of attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder (ADHD). Other drugs used for this indication are amphetamines, atomoxetine and pemoline

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents to your office for a regular check-up. Her only complaint is recurrent migraine headaches, which have increased in frequency over the years. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated at 150/70 mmhg. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs would be best to use for prophylaxis of migraines?
questions.solution:
• The β -blocker propranolol is a good choice for an antihypertensive medication.
  • However, it is also successfully used for other indications, such as prophylaxis of migraine headaches, situational anxiety, and hyperthyroidism-induced palpitations.

Indications of β -blockers :


Option A,B,C : The other choices are all acceptable antihypertensive medications, but from this list, only propranolol is used for migraine prophylaxis.

Key Takeaway:

Propranolol is the most commonly used drug for prophylaxis of migraine attacks. Timolol, atenolol, metoprolol and nadolol can also be used but the drugs with ISA (e.g. pindolol) are ineffective.

questions.text: Intravenous administration of epinephrine to a patient results in a severe decrease in diastolic pressure and an increase in cardiac output. Which of the following drugs might the patient have previously taken that could account for this unexpected effect?
questions.solution:
• Prazosin is the only drug listed that blocks postjunctional α1-adrenoceptors and inhibits epinephrine-mediated vasoconstriction.
  • The α blockers abolish the pressor action of Adrenalin (injected i.v. in animals), which then produces only fall in BP due to β2 mediated vasodilatation
  • This was first demonstrated by Sir HH Dale (1913) and is called vasomotor reversal of Dale.
  • Pressor and other actions of selective α agonists (phenylephrine) are suppressed.

Prazosin

  • It is first of the highly selective α1 blockers
  • α1 : α2 selectivity ratio 1000:1. All subtypes of α1 receptor (α1A, α1B, α1D) are blocked equally.
  • It blocks sympathetically mediated vasoconstriction and produces fall in BP which is attended by only mild tachycardia, because NA release is not increased due to absence of α2 blockade.

Option A: Propranolol blocks vasodilatation and fall in BP evoked by isoprenaline and enhances the rise in BP caused by Adr.

There is re-reversal of vasomotor reversal that is seen after α blockade

Option B: cholinergic impulses are not involved in the maintenance of vascular tone, atropine does not have any consistent or marked effect on BP. Atropine blocks vasodepressor action of cholinergic agonists.

Option C : It is a selective α1 agonist, with negligible β action. It raises BP by causing vasoconstriction.

Key Takeaway:

  • When an α blocker has been given, only fall in BP is seen which was first described by Dale, and is called vasomotor reversal of Dale. The α blockers abolish the pressor action of Adr (injected i.v. in animals), which then produces only fall in BP due to β2 mediated vasodilatation.

questions.text: Drug X causes an increase in blood pressure and a decrease in heart rate when administered to a patient intravenously. If an antagonist at ganglionic nicotinic receptors is administered first, drug X causes an increase in blood pressure and an increase in heart rate. Drug X most likely resembles which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
• In the absence of a nicotinic receptor antagonist, norepinephrine may result in a reflex baroreceptor-mediated increase in vagal activity.
  • The presence of such an agent unmasks the direct stimulant effect of norepinephrine on heart rate.

Effects of Ganglion blockade:

Option A: Propranolol blocks vasodilatation and fall in BP evoked by isoprenaline and enhances the rise in BP caused by Adr.

There is re-reversal of vasomotor reversal that is seen after α blockade

Option C: Isoprenaline causes rise in systolic but marked fall in diastolic BP (β1-cardiac stimulation, β2- vasodilatation). The mean BP generally falls.

Option D: SELECTIVE β2 STIMULANTS include salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol and ritodrine. They cause bronchodilation, vasodilatation and uterine relaxation, without producing significant cardiac stimulation.

Key Takeaway:

  • Noradrenaline causes rise in systolic, diastolic and mean BP; it does not cause vasodilatation (no β2 action), peripheral resistance increases consistently due to α action.

questions.text: A 78 year old man with diabetic autonomic neuropathy brought to the medicine department with complaints of dizziness and fainting when arising from bed in the morning. Which of the following drugs would be most beneficial to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Midodrine is a selective α 1-adrenoceptor agonist that is used to treat postural (orthostatic) hypotension.

Midodrine:

  • Midodrine is an orally effective α1 receptor agonist. It is a prodrug, converted to an active metabolite, desglymidodrine, which achieves peak concentrations about 1 h after a dose of midodrine.
  • Midodrine-induced rises in blood pressure are associated with contraction of both arterial and venous smooth muscle.
  • This is advantageous in the treatment of patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension.
  • A frequent complication in these patients is supine hypertension.

Option A: Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist. The only prominent action of clinically employed doses (2-8 μg/kg/min i.v. infusion) is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.

Option B: Salbutamol (albuterol)and terbutaline are fast acting drugs by inhalation route, so they are used for aborting an attack of acute asthma.

Option D: Clonidine is α2 agonist and decreases the central sympathetic outflow. It decreases blood pressure as well as heart rate.

Key Takeaway:

  • Midodrine is a selective α 1-adrenoceptor agonist that is used to treat postural (orthostatic) hypotension.

questions.text: A study was conducted to see the effect of different drugs on isolated mammalian intestinal tissue in Dale's organ bath. The following graph is obtained. Which of the following is the likely drug?
questions.solution:
EFFECT OF DRUGS ON RABBIT ILEUM EXPERIMENT

  • Parasympathetic drugs like ACh stimulate rabbit ileum (increase tone and frequency) that is blocked on pretreatment with atropine.
  • Similarly, sympathomimetics inhibit rabbit ileum contractions which is abolished by pre-treatment with beta-blockers

Identifying the unknown drug

Key Takeaway:

  • In isolated preparations of the gut, activation of both α and β receptors produces relaxation. In intact animals and man peristalsis is reduced and sphincters are constricted

questions.text: A 25-year-old man complained to his physician of painful erection and impaired ejaculation during intercourse. Three weeks earlier, he had been diagnosed with Raynaud's disease and had started an appropriate therapy. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of actions most likely caused the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Vasospasm in the fingers, which is the most common sign of Raynaud disease, is treated by a vasodilator, usually A calcium channel blocker, such as nifedipine, An α1 antagonist , such as prazosin.
  • The patient here most likely received prazosin because he complained of impaired ejaculation. The increased firing of the sympathetic nervous system that occurs during sex activates α1 receptors located on the vas deferens and prostate capsule.
  • The contraction of smooth muscles of these organs puts the semen into the urethra, thus causing ejaculation.

Prazosin blocks α1 adrenoceptors, so ejaculation is impaired.

Other Options : beta 2, M3 & Alpha 2 are Not related to Prostatic Urethra and Ejaculations.

Key Takeaway:

  • Contractions of vas deferens and seminal vesicles which result in ejaculation are coordinated through α receptors. As such, α blockers can inhibit ejaculation; this may manifest as impotence.

questions.text: A 35 year old healthy volunteer had taken part in phase I clinical trial in which he was administered an unknown drug 'X'. The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'?
questions.solution:
Beta Receptors Action :

Comparative effects of iv infusion of following agents:

Approach to Question :

Raised SBP : Either Alpha 1 / Beta 1

Decreased DBP : Beta 2

Reflex Tachycardia : Due to Vasodilation by Beta 2.

Option A: Alpha 1 Agonist Raises DBP and Reflex Bradycardia So It's Out.

Option B: M2 & M3 Agonist Doesn't Alter BP Significantly.

Option C: Alpha 1 Antagonist & Beta 2 agonist both decreases DBP so it's out.

Key Takeaway:

  • Isoprenaline causes rise in systolic but marked fall in diastolic BP (β1-cardiac stimulation, β2- vasodilatation). The mean BP generally falls.

questions.text: A new autonomic drug was administered locally in the conjunctival sac of a healthy volunteer. Twenty minutes later, measurement of several eye parameters gave the following results given in a table below. Which of the following pairs of receptors did the drug most likely activate?
questions.solution:
• Pupillary diameter can be increased either by the activation of α1 receptors (which contracts the radial muscle of the iris) or by the blockade of M3 receptors (which relaxes the sphincter muscle of the iris).
  • Intraocular pressure can be decreased by a decreased production or by an increased outflow of aqueous humor.
  • A decreased production can follow either the activation of α2 receptors or the blockade of β2 receptors.

Role of Adrenergic system on Aqueous humor dynamics

Option B : Beta Blockers can Reduce IOP. ( Not Agonist )

Option C : Activation of Nn receptors would cause an increase in sympathetic as well as parasympathetic firing. This would lead to an activation of M3 receptors in the ciliary muscle, which would lead to an activation of the iris sphincter muscle, which would decrease pupillary diameter.

Activation of Nm receptors causes the contraction of skeletal muscles only

Option D : Beta Blockers can Reduce IOP. ( Not Agonist )


Key Takeaway:

  • Mydriasis occurs due to contraction of radial muscles of iris (α1). The intraocular tension tends to fall, especially in wide angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman recently diagnosed with open-angle glaucoma, started treatment with timolol eye drops. Which of the following sets of effects most likely occurred shortly after the administration of the drug?
questions.solution:
• Timolol
    • It is the prototype of ocular β blockers; is nonselective (β1 + β2) and has no local anaesthetic activity. The ocular hypotensive action (20-35% fall in i.o.t.) becomes evident within 1 hour and lasts for ~12 hours the action is smooth and well sustained.
    • Beta-blockers decrease aqueous humor production by blocking β receptors in the ciliary epithelium.

Advantages of topical β blockers

  • No change in pupil size, no diminution of vision in dim light and in patients with cataract
  • No induced myopia which is especially troublesome in young patients
  • No headache/brow pain due to persistent spasm of iris and ciliary muscles
  • No fluctuations in i.o.t. as occur with pilocarpine drops
  • Convenient twice/once daily application sufficient
    • Beta-blockers have negligible effects on pupillary diameter (which is under the control of M3 receptors on the sphincter muscle of the iris and of α1 receptors on the radial muscle of the iris) and on lens curvature (which is mainly under the control of M3 receptors on the ciliary muscle).

Mode of actions for different anti-glaucoma drugs

Key Takeaway:

  • Timolol is the prototype of ocular β blockers; is nonselective (β1 + β2) and has no local anaesthetic or intrinsic sympathomimetic activity. It does not change the pupil size, no diminution of vision in dim light and in patients with cataract.

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic woman presented to the emergency room with severe ocular pain and redness, decreased vision, colored halos, and nausea and vomiting. Ophthalmoscopy revealed anterior chamber inflammation, and tonometry measured an intraocular pressure of 48 mm Hg in the right eye. A diagnosis of an acute glaucoma attack was made, and two drugs were instilled in the conjunctival sac. Another drug was given by the same route 15 minutes later. Which of the following three drugs were most likely administered?
questions.solution:
• An acute glaucoma attack is usually the first symptom of acute angle-closure glaucoma, a disease associated with a closed anterior chamber angle.
  • When this occurs, intraocular pressure rises, because the obstruction of the peripheral iris prevents the normal drainage of aqueous humor from the eye.
  • An acute glaucoma attack is a medical emergency because vision can be lost quickly. Aqueous humor production must be decreased.
  • Therefore, a topical β-blocker (e.g.,timolol) and an α2 agonist (e.g., apraclonidine) are immediately administered.
  • Then pilocarpine is given to increase aqueous humor outflow (cholinergic drugs alone are generally ineffective when the intraocular pressure is more than 40 mm Hg).

Option B, C: Homatropine and scopolamine are contraindicated in angle-closure glaucoma because they induce mydriasis, which increases the risk of closing the anterior chamber.

Option D: Prazosin is ineffective in glaucoma.

Mannitol is not given topically, but intravenously, and is used to lower the intraocular pressure only if the response to the first treatment is inadequate.

Key Takeaway:

  • An acute glaucoma attack is a medical emergency because vision can be lost quickly. Aqueous humor production must be decreased.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented for routine ophthalmic examination. Tonometry measured an intraocular pressure of 28 mm Hg in both eyes. The patient had been suffering from complete atrioventricular (AV) block for 2 years. The ophthalmologist prescribed appropriate eye drops. Which of the following drugs was most likely included in the treatment?
questions.solution:
• The patient was most likely suffering from open-angle glaucoma.
  • Pilocarpine historically was the initial treatment of choice, but today it is used only as an alternative therapy when other drugs are contraindicated, as in this case.
  • In fact, systemic effects can occur even after a topical administration, especially in the elderly, secondary to inadvertent overdose due to poor administration technique.

Summary of Drugs used in Glaucoma

Option A: Beta-blockers are first-line therapy for glaucoma but are contraindicated in this case because of the AV block.

Option B: Prazosin is primarily used as an antihypertensive. Other uses are in Raynaud's disease and benign hypertrophy of prostate (BHP).

Option C: Not used clinically

Key Takeaway:

  • Pilocarpine is used only in the eye as 0.5-4% drops. It is a third-line drug in open angle glaucoma. It is used only as an alternative therapy when other drugs are contraindicated

questions.text: An infant was brought to an ophthalmologist with congenital glaucoma (as shown in the figure below) for treatment. Which one of the following anti-glaucoma drug should be best avoided in infant to avoid adverse reactions?
questions.solution:
α2 AGONISTS: Apraclonidine & Brimonidine

MOA: It ↓ Aqueous formation

Side effects

  • Lid retraction
  • Dry Mouth
  • Ocular burning and allergic conjunctivitis
  • Brimonidine is less likely to cause ocular allergy
  • These can cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates and are contraindicated in children < 2 years

Summary of Adverse Effects of Anti-Glaucoma medications

Key Takeaway:

  • This clonidine congener is more α2 selective and more lipophilic than apraclonidine. It lowers i.o.t. by 20-27% by reducing aqueous production and by increasing uveoscleral flow. Brimonidine can cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates so contraindicated in children < 2 years
